title: Spool Filament Guide for FolgerTech FT-5

description.text:
Are you tired of nursing full rolls of filament during a print so the filament doesn't come off the side of the spool and tangle? I sure was so I designed this filament guide which eliminates the problem!
It's made of 3 parts > two identical sides and one end guide piece. You just slip the sides onto the 1/2" metal conduit (or smaller rod) so that the interlocking bevels are facing outward. Then feed the filament through the end guide and slide both side pieces into the slots until they snap into place.

To change spools, just push the interlocks inward and slip the end guide off. While I made this for the FolgerTech FT-5, it certainly will find many other applications.

One thing of note is that this is a snug fit so make sure you have your extrusion multiplier dialed in for a 0.48 wall thickness and your ESteps are correct. If you overextrude, it won't fit.

Since it was a snug fit for those who don't have their printers dialed in, I gave an extra 0.5mm gap on the updated files. I also made the guide area for the filament narrower so it stays more in the center of the roll. I also radiused the edges to help guide the filament more smoothly.

I've also included a set for wider rolls with the same improvements. Hope they help you! They help me!

Also, IF you hang on to the end of the filament from the time you cut it free from the roll and immediately pass it through this gadget, you will NOT have any snagging of the filament under other loops.

title: Toy Smart Phone
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a toy smart phone I designed for my daughter. She loves pretending to text and talk (but not while driving!) and wanted a phone with a different color case.

The original size file prints about the size of an iPhone 6. I had to reduce the size and make the phone and case separately to fit the plate on my Makerbot Replicator Mini +. But I included all the files in case anyone wanted to print on a larger plate.

I did not print the original size files or the file that has the phone and the case, but the only thing i changed was the length dimension so they should print fine.

The phone fits snuggly in the case but can be removed (with some effort and most likely adult help) if so desired.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini+

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I used rafts just because I don't have good luck printing without them on my Mini+. If you have good luck printing large flat objects without curling or slipping on your printer, rafts would be optional.

title: Refil 3D Mini Beast
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A corexy printer designed with ease of assembly, use and maintenance in mind. All rods on the build can be easily removed without removing any of the parts that hold them from the frame.

I am continuously updating the parts lists below and the models of the parts as I try new parts and improve the existing ones.

The printer build uses 2020 extrusions to keep the cost of low, while building a solid printer.

The current plan is for a 300x300x300mm build volume. You could use any parts you want to adjust the volume, however any bigger than 400x400x400 is not advised due to the parts designed for 2020 extrusions.

Using 2020 extrusions is a requirement, otherwise the parts will not fit!!

A list of all the parts needed to complete the build will be provided shortly after the full build is ready and tested.

Plastic Parts to print:
2 x Z Motor Mounts
8 x Z Rod Holders (pick the right version for 8mm or 10mm rods)
1 x Left Y Motor Mount (V2 part)
1 x Right Y Motor Mount (V2 part)
1 x Left Y Rod Mount (V2 part)
1 x Right Y Rod Mount (V2 part)
8 x Bearing Standoffs
1 x Endstop Clicker
1 x Endstop Mount for Y-axis
2 x Bed Mounts(set)

List of Parts you need:
Parts for the 300 model (300mmx300mmx300mm):
2 x 450mm 2040 extrusions
6 x 450mm 2020 extrusions
4 x 500mm 2020 extrusions
4 x 300mm 2020 extrusions (for mounting the bed)
Total I paid for extrusions is £115 but you can find them cheaper ~£60, especially if you can cut them to length yourself (mine were cut to length and anodized black)

2 x 10mm 450mm smooth rods £25.30
2 x 10mm 430mm smooth rods £24.20
4 x 8mm 400mm smooth rods for Z axis £31.60
4 x LMH8LUU 8mm Linear Bearing for Z Axis £22
2 x 8mm Lead Screw 370mm for Z axis £15

12V 280W 300*300mm Flexible Silicone Heating bed £18
PSU £30

Parts for the 400 model (400mmx400mmx400mm):
For the 400 model, just add 100mm to all of the extrusions, rods and the lead screws.

Parts for both versions:
5M GT2 Belt and 2 Pulleys £14.50
8 x Igus Drylin LM10UU Bearings (you can use regular 10mm bearings but these are quiet) £15
1 x Arduino 2560 £6
1 x RAMPS 1.4 £6
5 x DRV8825 Stepper Drivers £5.10
5 x NEMA 17 Motors (2 driving the bed can be long ones with higher torque) £40
1 x E3D v6 Full Metal (Can be either bowden or direct, 1.75mm/3mm, your choice) £52
1 x E3D Titan Extruder (Need 2 for dual colour and an extra NEMA 17!) £59
10 x F623ZZ Flange Ball Bearing Shielded 3 X 10 X 4mm £18

Facebook Group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/641612192699533/

Notes:

Settings you print are your choice. I would recommend PLA for all of the parts due to the rigidness, making a very solid printer. I would not use any ABS parts other than very close to the hotend or parts touching the bed (not any close to the bed i think)

title: Solar USB Charger w/ Voltage Monitors

description.text:
Great solar charger project. Will charge any USB device. This charger has two voltage monitors, one for charging input (solar panel or wall charger) and one for battery voltage so you know when you're getting low. Plus, the solar panel is on a hinge to get the best angle towards the sun.

Voltage meters plug into additional ports on the Lithium Ion Solar Charger with female connectors or can be soldered. All wires can be run neatly in a channel under the voltage meters.

I'm sure you could build one of these with cheaper components, but I had all of this stuff already and disassembled some old projects to build this. Enjoy!

Parts list:
Large 6V 3.4W Solar Panel
https://www.adafruit.com/products/500
Solar Lithium Ion Charger
https://www.adafruit.com/products/390
Lithium Ion Battery Pack 6600mAh
https://www.adafruit.com/products/353
MintyBoost USB Board
https://www.adafruit.com/products/14
Mini Panel Meter
http://www.mpja.com/Mini-Panel-Meter-Panel-Mount-2-Wire-25-30VDC/productinfo/32320+ME

You will also need a 2.1mm barrel jack plug, 2 M6x30 bolts, washers and nuts.

comments.text: Not good ! You DON'T twist a timing belt ! The REAL solution is simply a toothed idler pulley.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Actually this is how most of CoreXY printers are working and it is indeed recommended to twist the belts by 180 degree, because of the friction of each belt on the idler which leads to artifacts.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Is it a CoreXY ? NO ! Please refer to technical docs regarding timing belts. The fact some people twist their belt doesn't make it right, certainly not here. Besides, the majority of people here and in the 3D printer hobby world have close to no  expertise in mechanic.
comments.author: nurtext

comments.text: Sure it's not a CoreXY, but as Bebop182 already stated, having a idler with teeth would be the best option.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
CoreXY or not is irrelevant, the best way is of course to have a toothed idler. Twisting the belt will put more strain on the xaxis near the edge. In any case having the belt teeth against a smooth pulley will wear it down and may induce imprecision.
But MKSA engineering is not a cult, there is no such commandment as: "You DON'T twist a timing belt" -- Some prick in 2016.
You do whatever you can to improve efficiency with what you have at your disposal. Leave the preaching to the priest.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Just ignore MKSA... he might be an intelligent guy, but if you look on most Geeetech related things here he's left a comment telling the maker why they're stupid... and why everyone's stupid because we don't all use his designs... and why he's the smartest guy in the room always. It's a pathetic cry for attention and I'm sick of seeing his asinine comments everywhere I turn. I have never met such a rude an arrogant human being in real life, but hey, it's the internet... there should be a block feature on here so we can turn him off. For real, i'm not knocking the guy on designs and ideas, he's often not wrong... he just radiates negativity though and never has anything polite to say on here. I think it's a clever idea you came up with, and that's what being a maker is all about. We don't all have to be mechanical engineers on here and if you are good for you, but don't act like everyone else is lesser and needs to pack up and go home because you have a different idea MKSA!
comments.author: Bebop182

comments.text:
The core XY uses long belts and because of the long free length twisting them is less of a problem. Anyway, the smart guy will find a way to perform AND the function AND respect proper rules.
And spare me your patronizing.
comments.author: Bebop182

comments.text: I don't see why you would not. It is a 180° twist over 300mm+ course. If you have a toothed pulley it's great, but nothing wrong will happen to you if you don't.
comments.author: MKSA

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dHPvbFURnb5
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/awHmM2Igkxw

This is a tool designed for a patient who had lost his index, middle and ring finger and conserves the first phalanx of the thumb and pinky finger on his left hand (refer to pictures).
This allows him to perform tip grip and hold a nail or a screw.

The thimble had a PLA framework, a silicone body, and a magnet. The silicone body is fabricated by pouring silicone inside a mold (refer to pictures)

The framework has a circular pattern that allow a better attachment of the silicone and has a prolongation to avoid hiperflexion of the patient thumb. The fluted mold shape is for better suspension over the patient stump.

This object was made for the "Mutual de Seguridad C.Ch.C" from Chile. In a project of the Direction of Innovation and Development, and the Neuro Rehabilitation Institute.

Printer Brand:

Leapfrog

Printer:

Creatr XL

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

15

The process uses 3-D printed polylactic acid (PLA) for the molds and the inside structure. It also uses silicone elastomer (25A Shore).
First, silicone is poured inside the mold that surround the exterior of the socket. Then the inside structure, with a magnet inserted on its tip, is embedded inside the silicone and then the mold is closed with the finger shape mold. The silicone is cured at room temperature for 40 minutes. Finally, molds are removed and the socket is finished.

You can use moisturizing cream as mold release agent

remixed_from.author: Tuga_75
remixed_from.title: Prusa MK2 Extruder For BQ Prusa I3

description.text:
Hey all!

Had a BQ Prusa i3 laying around that never worked with the Witbox extruder. So I decided to modify something to make a Bowden setup.

You can use any extruder, but the one I included is just a mod of the Thingybot extruder. It uses a MK7 drive gear and 608 bearing.

To install the E3D -

Attach the body to the X carriage using two M3 20mm screws.

Place the E3D hot end in the mount

Put the top cover with 40mm fan mount on and screw it into the extruder body using two M3 16mm screws.

Attach the 30mm hot end fan on the side

Attach the 40mm part cooling fan on the front

For the extruder -

Using 3x M3 8mm screws attach the extruder body to the stepper motor

Align the MK7 drive gear to the filament hole

Attach the Bowden push fit connector

Take the idler, put the 608 bearing on it, then add the cap with a M3 12mm screw

Attach the idler to the extruder using a M3 16mm screw

Put a M3 nut into the hole by the filament inlet

Put a M3 16mm screw through the idler and into the nut you just placed

That's it! Just "hang" it like the spool holder that comes with the BQ i3.

Notes -

You can use the heater cartridge and thermistor from the Witbox hot end on the E3D so you dont need to rewire anything.

You can also splice the fan cables to the 30mm and 40mm fans to make installation easier.

That should be it, if anyone has any questions let me know!

description.text: Small bearing ring with a single ball to be duplicated as needed.

This derivative of the original Bathtube U-Boat has been cleaned up tested with the current generation of slicing tools. Skinforge was primitive and slow, but it would slice anything eventually. MakerWare and Slic3r are much more efficient, but can't readily cope with the geometric errors present in many older models The clean-up was done using Netfabb Basic and the SketchUp plug-ins SolidInspector and CleanUp. Solid Inspector is available for download here: http://extensions.sketchup.com/en/content/solid-inspector CleanUp is available for download here:

author: skinnyp

title: AIO FPV Camera Mount for Parrot Rolling Spider Frame

description.text:
Camera holder / mount for Parrot Rolling Spider frame.

Disclaimer: I have no printer to test the design myself, so I can't promise about fit and function. If you print this and find design issues, please feel free to tell me.

UPDATE: 23 Apr 2017 - I've been using the latest verison for a while, and seems there's no one complaining, I'm removing "Work in Progress" status. Any suggestions or ideas of improvement are still appreciated.

UPDATE: 7 Mar 2017 - Earlier design keep breaking at side wiring slots, I removed them to improve durability, instead opened lower corners from the rear to allow easier access to flight controller / battery.

UPDATE: 7 Dec 2016 - A friend printed test pieces of both versions, due to messed up print settings I had to drill out the 3 holes to 1.8mm to fit the 3 posts on Rolling Spider frame. Also further enlarged foot print to 20.5x10.5mm
UPDATE: 13 Nov 2016 - Updated dimensions for loose fit, allowing footprint up to 19.5x9.5mm.

Designed for use with FX798T or similar sized camera.

Most decased AIO FPV camera should fit with room for sticky foam tape, as long as total footprint is within 19x8.5 19.5x9.5 20.5x10.5mm.
Slots and holes to allow access for wiring and switches on some camera models.
Distance between base of camera and roof of frame is approx. 18mm in 15 degree version.

NOTE: I believe cameras with stiff cloverleaf antenna will have fitting issues, e.g. hitting antenna when larger props are used. Recommended modding with whip antenna.

You may want to put a small dab of hot glue between mount & frame for secure installation while still removable.

Design includes 15 / 20 / 22.5 degree versions, I screwed up a little bit so 22.5 degree is max tilt angle in current design.

A 15 degree version with some sort of roll cage for poops and giggles, or when you really need the extra protection.

comments.text: Any chance of making a version that fits the Mambo frame? I found they were about half the cost of a Rolling Spider frame.
comments.author: brucesdad13

comments.text: Never seen a Mambo in person, judging from the pictures of Mambo spare parts, I would say you won't want to build a quad with just a Mambo frame alone.
comments.author: brucesdad13

comments.text: I broke my parrot rolling spider frame in half that's how I ended up grabbing the mambos :D Ok was worth a shot :D
comments.author: kwongkan

comments.text:
It might still work if the posts mounting the face plate are in same position (but I doubt it).
If that's the case, trim off both front tip of Mambo Frame and rear end of this camera mount should allow mounting.
comments.author: brucesdad13

comments.text: I crashed into my chimney :D I didn't noticed it was broken in half until after I came inside. The rubber bands I use to hold the flight controller tray in place were holding it all together in compression. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Pts3vGp0YM
comments.author: kwongkan

comments.text: Ouch, please don't hug your chimney again, it's painful to watch, LOL.
comments.author: brucesdad13

comments.text:
Hi,
I love your design!!
comments.author: moninox

comments.text: I will probably measure a de-cased FX798T, add some clearance and it would fit most AIO cameras, stay tuned.

comments.text:
Is the current file already updated for the fx798t?
Thanks

comments.text: Yep, I'm using a de-cased FX798T on current version, you may want to add a few layers of sticky foam tape to adjust fitment, as I was making the model on the loose side, hoping to fit most AIO VTX cam on the market.

print_settings.Notes:: At best print the ScrewCap(s) with a lot of infill so they do not break while screwing them in hard.

description.text:
A cute little monster head which will vomit the drink of your choice into your glass. It can be screwed on any regular plastic bottle. There is a extra cap that can be screwed in the mouth. The cap for closing the mouth is however not 100% tight, when you screwed it on solid and you put it upside down drops will slowly come out.

This a remix of one my Bottle Monsters which you can find here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1016582

There is no Support required. The mouth screw caps should have high infill.

I don't know how food save any 3d printing plastics are but I can however ensure you that I have not died yet and I will let you know here If this changes. Though it goes without saying you should make sure that your 3d printing is clean so that there are no tiny bits that can break of which can easily be the case with a print that did not come out perfect.

You have the choice:
Monster.STL or Monster-Tongue.STL (has a tongue which leads the drink a little better)
ScrewCap.STL or ScrewCap-Vomit.STL (Vomit like looking cap)
For the eyes the Iris parts are optional (they need to be glued in), there is also a variation with more tolerance in case you need that. You have to put in the eyes with some force in any case though.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

At best print the ScrewCap(s) with a lot of infill so they do not break while screwing them in hard.

description.text: conversion of the MK8 extruder into a dual bowden extruder. Turned upside down and adapted for 1/8 BSP push-fit connectors. Still need to design the head end, probably from aluminium. Changed design slightly after 1st print needed beefing up a bit. snapped the push-fit clamp fitting nut. Second version seems much stronger, the push-fits seem in there pretty tight. Mount uploaded plus New Version of base to accommodate changes for nuts to hold parts together instead of threading abs holes. I now have the new setup working, and working well, much less shaking of the case, it even sounds less strained when making fast moves. Just need to tidy up my cables Added V3 of mount, now has cable management runs through the back. Link to it in action on the tube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jFWJ6pfuvgc

converted from a single MK8. The push-fit locking screws are M3x16. Head end is threaded for 1/8 BSP seems to be tight and strong enough fitted with a 0.5mm thick washer to keep them stood off the extruder mounting block and as cool as possible. Reverse fit the heatsinks and fans using printed shrouds, and used 30mm M3 bolts instead of the longer original ones to hold it all together.

comments.text: What JKN Advance K and K2 values are you using with this setup? I assume you are using Sailfish firmware

comments.text: I really like the design of this extruder and have printed some of the parts already. Planning to use it to replace extruders in an old Rapman 3.1 I have and need to switch to 1.75 filament. Can anyone tell me what the bearing numbers are? I'm finding several options, but none fit exactly. Plus, are they grooved? It appears in your picture that the drive gear is not, so is the bearing?
comments.author: jbchron

comments.text: The bearing is a 10x5mm 4mm wide just smooth. The drive gears I have are the original ones from the printer they are not grooved either, just a very sharp set of teeth the whole length much finer than on the grooved kind. I have not had any problems with the filament wandering. Looking again at the design a grooved drive might move the centre of the filament toward the drive side a bit but hopefully not enough to mess up the feed.

author: nghochaghi

title: Manipulative snap-together sprues to create polygons, polyhedra, molecules etc

description.text:
Meant originally to teach the relationships between angle measures and side lengths in triangles and polygons in general.  The power here is that you can make polygons with unusual angles and side lengths -- thus requiring students to measure.  If used correctly, many protractors will lay right across the top for easy measurement.  
Because I couldn't find any connecting objects with length options which were relatively prime, I decided to make some.  Here we have evenly spaced rings and vertical pins, but horizontal pins are arranged in a slightly different pattern allowing you to make regular or irregular polygons.  
These are for teaching plane geometry only; I haven't decided whether a 3D geometry version is warranted.  I have seen how amazed students are when they roll off the printer and students can suddenly build things!  
I usually make them at 1.25 magnification.

remixed_from.author: beyondwind
remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 direct extruder X Carriage mount with Blower

description.text:
upgraded X carriage for the I3X ( mine is a Geeetech acrylic frame version )

Saves 75% weight compared to stock ( mod V4 )

Based on Beyondwind & riansolutions (remix) design Things: 982921 & 1043124

I have included a Few significant improvements :

Printable Z height increased by 20mm ( extruder mounted higher much like stock carriage )

Cable mounting point

much much easier belt fitting

Mechanical end-stop trigger built in ( if needed )

Can use 3 or 4 LM8UU bearings or 2 LML8UU ( Mod & Mod V3 )

downside is this now needs support to print ( highly recommend using Cura 2.3 to slice & enable roof support & support everywhere, Print with endstop pointing up, rotate model 45 degrees clockwise on bed )

Update 26/10/16

modV3 alows for extruder motor to be mounted 15mm further towards the front of the machine if desired , this will allow the extruder motor to clear the X idler giving edge to edge print volume (215 mm on X axis ) , if motor is mounted in the forward position it will also allow more clearance for larger hotends.

modV4 includes all features of modV3 but only allows the use of 3 LM8UU bearings , uses 5 meters less filament and looks a bit smoother, makes for a very light setup ( 77g with 3 X LM8UU bearings , stock is 300g)

Video in action here : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f0oJqCsKulA
UPDATE 27/10/16

Fan Duct now available

Update 01/11/16

Early version files removed.

Update 12/10/16

Video Added.

Printer:

Geeetech I3X

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Print in ABS for heat resistance, all printed with a 0.4 nozzle , 0.2 layer height, 50 % infill , Walls 1.2mm

Carriage is tricky to print requires careful support settings & a Brim

Endstop mount - no support / 8 mm brim ( no brim if using PEI Bed )

Belt lock - no support / 8mm brim ( no brim if using PEI Bed )

Fan duct - Enable support

description.text:
This is a scan of the Bas relief made in stone by Andrea Bregno. The 3D scan has been made at the National Art Gallery museum in Copenhagen. All the pictures (103 in total) have been processed with Memento beta (now Remake) from Autodesk using photogrammetry technology. The 3D scan has been cleaned with Blender 2.73a and Netfabb 5.2.0, and sliced with Slic3r 1.2.6. The model has been prepared in such way to avoid too much overhanging and if printed slowly, should not need material support.

For more update, please follow @GeoffreyMarchal on Twitter.

comments.text: I printed this file last night, just after finishing calibrating the printer and doing the regular monthly maintenance interval.  I used just my basic Monoprice Maker Select V2 with the basic extruder and stability upgrades.  I printed this in eSun PLA+ (which can't really be beat for the price in that it's extremely consistent and hard to mess up, while being 4X stronger than PLA) in white on 0.15mm resolution since I did it overnight and to do 0.1 would have taken up a chunk of today as well.  Essentially, nothing special with the printer, filament, slicing, or anything else- just sliced it and hit print.

author: Bjarnuhh

description.text:
My first shot at creating a spinner using FreeCAD.

I've made the skate bearing holes 22.1mm in diameter to accommodate for the way it prints the holes smaller than 22mm on the Makerbot I use. This way it is a near perfect fit for me and only takes a little bit of sanding the holes..

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Links to some bearings you can use

Of course, you can spend a lot on hybrid or ceramic bearings. I just use stainless steel because they're more cost effective. If you want longer spin times, making the spinner out of a metal will help, but using a ceramic bearing will help a lot...they're just a lot more expensive.
I use my spinners simply as fidget toys. So U use some of these...

The bearings in the two sides are less expensive because they don't need to spin as smoothly, and if you make a lot of spinners, they're good to have around:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01C9XDPVQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

This is the one in the center I used for this one, it's a Bones Super Red bearing: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002E2MYSI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Bones Reds also work well for the cost, and I use them a lot in fidget spinners:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000FDRQ1S/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Yellow Jackets are good in my opinion:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00VKK3I6W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

title: Turnigy Fabrikator 3D Extruder Cover Plate For "J-Head MK-V Hot End"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
When the extruder on my Turnigy Fabrikator 3D (not “Mini”) jammed, I searched for an identical replacement, but could find none. So, I ended up using a "J-Head MK-V Hot End" instead (e.g. “http://www.ebay.com/itm/261990496377?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT”). This caused some complications, but I solved them all, and I’m sharing that information here.

First, purchase a "J-Head MK-V Hot End" that matches the filament specs of the original. This means you'll want a "J-Head MK-V Hot End" with a 0.4mm nozzle diameter and 1.75mm filament diameter.

When your "J-Head MK-V Hot End" arrives, you’ll notice that it does not fit into the printer. You’ll therefore need to shave down the neck of the extruder slightly until it fits. If you use a rotary tool, it takes 10 minutes.

Once the new extruder is installed and wired back up, go into Cura’s machine settings and reduce the Z build volume from 100 to 80.

Finally, print and install my new cover plate using the old screws and magnets. The new cover plate is designed to help prevent jams by aiming some cool air at the cool end of the extruder.

title: Prusa i3 MK2 and MK2S : Y Axis corner block replacement

description.text:
Update 15 March 2017:
More update coming for MK2S version.

Update 30 Oct 2016:
Work in progress, removed rear block as there is a flaw in design and dimension. Will udpate soon.

Update 7 Nov 2016:
Design completed, I had printed but yet to install it as i am waiting for my motor damper.

Update 8 Nov 2016:
Installation completed, final fine alignment is done by tighten the prints (compression).

Original Prusa Mk2 kit is hard to build and extremely hard to align. It is assume that a well aligned printer will be quiet and less uneven wear to your bearings.

This is a modified Y-axis block is designed to be a drop in replacement for the "Original Corner Blocks"

All file are version 5.0.

Print time is 4 hour per block.

  1. Front - 3.5 hours
  2. Rear - 4.0 hours
  3. Y motor mount - 1.0 hour
  4. 100mm Left Z to rear - 0.5 hour (optional)
  5. 80mm Right Z to rear - 0.5 hour (optional)

Adv:
Can be use together with LCD without problem.
Drop in replacement, use lesser nuts and bolts.
Ideal position for Y motor mount
Work with damper or without damper motor configuration (Just need to offset pulley)
Work with IGUS RJZM-01-08, which is 16mm in diameter (1mm bigger than default lm8uu)
Easier way to make PRUSA perpendicular

Some tips by Ryan Neufeld for squaring the printer
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4KgG3XVU5so

Note:

  1. Motor mount requires 2x nut and washer to compress against rear block
  2. I did my print at fast speed, hence sanding was required at some area

Credit to Aaron Yourk and Joseph Tam for their input and inspiration.
Aaron had also made a remix of this design:
https://www.tinkercad.com/users/7Z01p6EVg8r-aaron-yourk

Printer:

Original Prusa MK2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Perimeter Shell is 5, Top and Bottom Layer is 3

title: Dual Blower/Radial Fan Duct Mount (Tevo Tarantula)

description.text:
A simple, easy to print (20mins) fan duct for Tevo Tarantula.
(An interchangeable version https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2346783)

If you print small parts / bridge / overhang, extreme cooling is needed. According to http://www.desiquintans.com/coolingtests2 and http://www.desiquintans.com/coolingtests, blower fan seems like the way to go as it supplies higher air pressure and can be directed better. I chose dual blowers for max cooling and evenly-distributed airflow (surround-style rarely provides even, symmetric air in practice) and medium nozzle open to match the fan's CFM and power. The duct has no right angles or compression spots that slow down the airflow and is directed underneath the hotend to avoid cooling the hotend and heat block.

Printing orientation : Print the duct upside down.
Installation : Just connect the fans in parallel. Combine the +'s and -'s of each fan together to form a single pair of +, -, then connect them to the board as you would with a single fan.

The design snug-fits this blower fan:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MJU6JR2/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Fusion360 file is attached for educational / modification purposes.

Using this duct with 0.2mm layer:
5cm Bridge Torture Test Photo #3 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12925/#files.
Cooling Tower Test Photo #4 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1015641

Printing tips: For most / big prints where each layer has enough time to cool, fan speed can be set to 50-70% without any noticeable degrade in quality or use the wide-nozzle design. But for small parts / overhang, more cooling just generally gives better results and it's good to have a setup that provides such a power if ever needed. This duct at 100% is very powerful and at lower layers, air will bounce off the bed and partially reach the hotend which could lower the temperature of the hotend. In cura, fan speed can be gradually increased with "regular fan speed at layers" options. Set this to some layers or certain height once there's a good clearance between the bed and hotend. You can also increase the hot end temperature to compensate or run PID tuning with fans on at your desired speed if you really need to run at high speed.

Update 5/25/17: A new platform with a little wider clearance.
Update 3/16/17: Added fillet. Added a wide-nozzle design.
Update 11/5/2016: Increased the distance between two fans to improve the heat sink airflow + A new snug-fit platform.
Update 11/11/2016: Added fusion 360 source file.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

20

comments.text:
Thanks 10izfrky
I'm also using Cura. Wall 1mm (2 shells), speed 60mm/s. layer 0.2mm.
I'd try printing it again with the new fan duct. Your actual hotend temp is normal during printing right? If you're not talking about sagging (not enough cooling), see if your temp didn't go too low. That sometimes can cause stringing (before jamming) especially when there's not enough surface to stick to.

description.text: This is my lofted gear vase made in SolidWorks.

Every part needs a backside. Simply mirror every part and superglue them together.
The upper mid section needs just the right amount of support for the place where the hook will be inserted. Careful with the right angle amount so support isnt added to the beveled edge of those parts but insted where it is supposed to be. You will figure it out.
Where the hook is inserted I used superglue at the bottom and held the hook in place until stuck. Then filled up around it with thicker glue.

author: bish_boy80

description.text:
Attention PMC jewelry makers!
This thing is a PMC ring former. Use it to form ring blanks out of PMC (Precious Metal Clay). Once the ring blank is formed, you can add detail to it or fire it as is.
The STL and DXF files are scaled for a size 7 ring blank. I do not know the finished size after firing. I'll try to remember to post the size after I finally fire one of these.
RR1_C1 and RR1_C2 replace part RR1_C, making it easier to remove the PMC ring blank. Hold the two halves together with rubber bands until the PMC is dry.

1) Print the pieces (PLA works best). Print part D upside down for best results.
2) Lubricate all parts with veg oil or as recommended by the PMC manufacturer. 
3) Stack part B onto part A.
4) Add part C onto parts A and B.
5) Roll up some PMC and feed it into the ring shaped cavity.
6) Using part D, pack the PMC down into the mold. Use firm pressure. Part E may be used to help push part D to form the ring blank. 
7) Allow to dry. You can place the entire thing in a toaster oven set for 150F for 30 minutes (might take a couple of times) to speed up the drying process. When dry, carefully remove the ring blank.
8) Detail the ring blank and fire as directed by the PMC manufacturer.
9) Show off your new ring by wearing it.

comments.text: This is an awesome idea!
comments.author: Menneset

comments.text: Very interesting idea.  Do you have any problems as the metal clay dries and shrinks?  Does the ring blank crack or stick to the center piece (A)?  Could you post a photos of a PMC blank you've made using the ring former?  Thanks!

comments.text: My second attempt, not so good. This may be a good idea, however I think it's a bad design. I'm thinking that if I make part C out of two halves, it will greatly simplify removal of the blank. The two halves could be held together with rubber bands.

title: Stain Glass with Clear Filament and Beads

description.text: Students will be working on creating a design in Morphi to create small pieces of clear 3D printed images with colored beads to design a stain glass design.
CCSS
Students will be working on creating a design in Morphi to create small pieces of clear 3D printed images with colored beads to design a stain glass design.

Step 1: Introduction (5 mins.)
History of Stain Glass - https://youtu.be/WInb5RgsahI Step 2: Creating with Morphi (include images)
Using the iPad app Morphi, students will start with a rectangular base. Show the ruler tool and have them select inches so that it is sized to 2 inches. Show them how the slider works when you click on the shape to increase the size of your shape. After creating the rectangular base, students need to use the drawing part of the app to create an image that is colored in. Step 3: Exporting the Design (screenshots of process)
Students will need to export the design for 3D printing from Morphi as an .stl file and share it with the teacher for final printing. Printing will take approximately 1 hour - 1.5 hours depending on the piece.
Rafts: yes
Supports: no
Resolution: 0.2 mm
Infill: 10% Step 4: Printing the Design
As the honeycomb interior is built, you will pause the design about half way through to add beads. After adding the beads, you will resume the build. Double the size of the original .stl otherwise you will end up too small. If you want 2 colors, you can change the filament midway through. Stop when about 10 minutes is left to add the beads.

Materials:
Clear filament
Seed Beads
Morphi App

title: Lattice Cube 3D Printer Torture Test (Overhangs and Dual-Extrusion)

description.text:
Can your printer handle this?

Based on the Makers Muse Lattice Cubes, this design is a similar thing in the sense that it is a lattice cube on a base. The super lattice cube is two lattice cubes rotated in on each other, and it makes everything look quite complicated. The Ultra is three, and the unsymmetric is two cubes, but not rotated in a way that makes them symmetric. That one was an accident, but I'll keep it up because why not?

This is a great test for overhangs, temperatures, cooling, and retraction.

See Maker's Muse on YouTube! He's the guy I got this idea from, and you should definitely check his channel out: https://www.youtube.com/user/TheMakersMuse

Because I was using AutoCAD (yes, CAD) on a laptop to make this, it isn't perfect. I'm not even sure it's a perfect cube, lol.

But anyway, this thing will put your printer to the test, so make sure to watch the print so it doesn't fail!

EDIT: 10-28: Added a dual-extruder version. I don't have a dual-extruder printer, so if there's something wrong, let me know!

EDIT: 7-18-17: Added a version of the super cube with no base. Someone wanted it, even though I don't think it'll work without a bunch of support material. Maybe if it was split in the middle and then glued together, it could work without supports, but you'd need some seriously good bed adhesion to do that.

EDIT: 7-19-17: Added no-base versions of all of the other lattice cubes, except the dual-extruder version.

HighFive

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

0.2mm layer height works well, but any lower and you risk failing like I did. Basically, the overhangs curl up a bit, and if you have a really small layer height, your extruder will run into that curling in a more severe way than if it were 0.2mm layer height.

I used AutoCAD 2016 on a laptop...

Took about 30 minutes to make it, but about 2 hours trying to get the software to work in the first place -_-

comments.text: Printed just fine on my Anet A8 with Bowden setup. Printed at 60mm/s, fan speed at 100%, 195C with Hatchbox black PLA, 0.2mm layer height. The most surprising part is that I printed at 0% infill, which made the base completely hollow (ie looong bridging). It got a little hairy there, but I let it go, and it all worked out. I'd definitely recommend some infill.

description.text:
Description (EN):

This is a protectionframe for the miniquad copter "Jumper" from Redbee. Usually the original breaks very fast, as well as in my case. Since there is currently no replacement to buy, I have a self-printable version made which can be attached without tools.

You do not know the "Jumper"? Then you can watch the videos below:

The frame also goes for the Eachine X73

Beschreibung (DE):

Dies ist ein Schutzrahmen für den Miniquad Copter "Jumper" von Redbee. Üblicherweise geht das Original sehr schnell kaputt, so wie auch in meinem Fall. Da es zur Zeit noch kein Ersatz zu kaufen gibt, hab ich mir eine selbstdruckbare Version gebustelt welche ohne Werkzeug befestigt werden kann.

Du kennst den Jumper nicht? Dann kannst du dir die Videos unten anschauen:

Das Frame geht auch für den Eachine X73

title: M3 Hex Driver (For FC/PDB nuts and standoffs)

description.text:
Handy tool for screwing/unscrewing M3 Hex nuts and standoffs.

Our FPV forum: http://www.IntoFPV.com
FB Multirotor Group: https://www.facebook.com/groups/Copter.Fans/

I printed mine with Ultimaker 2+ with Polymaker Filament. To account for shrinkage you might want to print the head first (stop at the first 10mm of the print), and see if it fits your hex hardware. Then scale it up or down if necessary.

NOTE!!
This is not for heavy duty uses. It's designed for RC Model nylon hardware. (You might use it with metal also but it could damage the tool if you turn to hard)

The hardware is 4-40 and the nuts are a tight press fit so they won't fall out.

I have designed this railing for my RC Garage top floor. It can be used as a barrier arm, Ladder (If you cut the top off) ETC. Up to you the possibilities are endless.
The dimensions are 20cm Long (200mm), 4.5cm High (45mm).
Please see the picture which was my inspiration.
Also this is not perfect as i am still learning. It may require sanding / holes drilling out better.
I have designed this so it will accommodate 3mm screws for the feet. You can also use glue, double sided tape etc. Up to you.

I have just added V2 Legs. 1 individual or 5 in a group. The V2 Legs have a 6mm hole in the base so the screw will go in and sit flat. (Please note i haven't printed the V2 only the 1st ones as i just drilled the 6mm hole)

I printed mine in white them painted using Tamiya spray paints.

remixed_from.author: ywabiko
remixed_from.title: Adafruit USB Micro-B Breakout Board Enclosure

description.text:
A tiny speaker system that consists of an analog amplifier and two speaker drivers.
There are 2 variants depending on amplifier.

  • Compo_PAM8403.stl // SainSmart PAM8403-based
  • Compo_MAX98306.stl // Adafruit MAX98306-based

Assembly requires following parts.

  • 1 x Amplifier: Sainsmart or Adafruit Stereo 3.7W Class D Audio Amplifier MAX98306.
  • 2 x 1" Speaker drivers Dayton Audio CE32A.
  • 2 x Small screws #4 3/8-in.
  • 1 x Adafruit Breadboard Friendly 3.5mm Stereo Headphone Jack.
  • 1 x Adafruit USB Micro-B Breakout Board Enclosure.

This model is a self remix from multiple models as follows.

  • CE32A 1" Speaker Driver Enclosure
  • PAM8403-based Tiny Audio Amplifier Board
  • Adafruit Stereo 3.7W Class D Audio Amplifier MAX98306 Enclosure
  • Adafruit Breadboard Friendly 3.5mm Stereo Headphone Jack Enclosure
  • Adafruit USB Micro-B Breakout Board Enclosure

小さなパワードスピーカーのようなものです。アナログアンプとスピーカー、音声入力用の3.5mm端子、電源用のMicro USB端子からなっています。
使用するアンプによって モデルは2種類あります(SainSmart PAM8403 D級ステレオアンプモジュール または Adafruit MAX98306。

  • Compo_PAM8403.stl // SainSmart PAM8403版
  • Compo_MAX98306.stl // Adafruit MAX98305版

組み立てに必要な部品は以下のとおりです。

  • 1 x アンプボード。SainSmart PAM8403 D級ステレオアンプモジュール または Adafruit MAX98306
  • 2 x 1インチスピーカードライバー Dayton Audio CE32A.
  • 2 x 木ねじ #4 3/8インチ、あるいは M2.2 x 10mm等の下穴直径2mm 深さ10mm前後のもの。
  • 1 x Adafruit Breadboard Friendly 3.5mm Stereo Headphone Jack.
  • 1 x Adafruit USB Micro-B Breakout Board Enclosure.

このモデルは以下のモデルの自己Remixとなっています。

  • CE32A 1" Speaker Driver Enclosure
  • PAM8403-based Tiny Audio Amplifier Board
  • Adafruit Stereo 3.7W Class D Audio Amplifier MAX98306 Enclosure
  • Adafruit Breadboard Friendly 3.5mm Stereo Headphone Jack Enclosure
  • Adafruit USB Micro-B Breakout Board Enclosure

description.text:
Flatbed train cars, compatible with popular 1" gauge wooden (and other) tracks.

These have "magnet pockets" on the ends to hold some 6.5mm N42 magnets I happened to have (like these: https://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=B444).

The wheels double as funky Lego mini-fig hats.

Letters are not included in these files.

Printer:

FlashForge Dreamer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.18mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

I am printing these out of ABS, tolerances may vary for PLA.

If you choose to switch to smaller diameter metal axles, I'd study the hub pattern of the commercial wheels (inside bolster)

I find that magnet insertion and wheel assembly to the axles go easier when the parts are hot out of the printer.

I have been printing these in three parts, all 4 wheels, then the carriage, then a pair of axles on a raft.

Assembly

Press fit 6.5mm magnet cubes in the pockets, careful to get the desired polarity.

Snap fit the wheels onto the axle/carriage, et voila' - flat bed train car. Attach your favorite topper and play.

OpenSCAD

Nothing fancy, the hull functions are handy for making the filleted wheels, but they take a long time to render.

I thought I was going to use acetone to bond the wheels to the axles, but it turns out that they snap-fit quite securely, without any bonding agent. Of course, you could always bond/glue them if you want.

title: Jointed Shoe Lacing Device
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I created a jointed hinge-type device to tie shoelaces.

There are some shoe lacing devices like Klots (quick shoe ties). But, after some use, they can be detached or broken when you are walking or running.

So I made it stronger, not untied, and more flexible by using hinge-like(cylindrical) joints.

When you also use other devices, to finish lacing shoes, you should tuck in your shoelace underneath the sole or cut the ends of the shoelace.

I present how to tie shoes with my device, without tucking in or cutting shoelaces:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3ESj-Q8hrFw

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer thickness

Infill:

100%

comments.text:
This is the best lace system I have found without a doubt.
I run with these at least 3 to 4 hours a day, 5 days a week and they have been perfect since January. Never came undone, never gave me a single problem.
comments.author: MHTSOS

comments.text:
The minimum tolerance is 0.2mm. My printer " Printrbot simple metal" doesn't have so good print quality. But, that is enough, I think.
Please adjust the flow rate in Cula. I recommend 80~90% flow rate.
comments.author: MHTSOS

comments.text: Just an update. The Carbon Fiber PLA have finished and they snapped loose perfectly and cleanly. In fact so clean that it is amazing considering what hell the Glow in the Dark filament gave me. Again both filaments were Hatchbox brand so I put it to the fact that the Glow in the dark filaments I have, seem to be more rubbery. You would never notice it but after printing these in the carbon fiber, I see how the glow in the dark would bend rather than snap, if given enough pressure.
comments.author: tigermcho

comments.text: I tried the flow rate also but it was to no avail. That being said I only print at .1 or lower but I think it was the glow in the dark filament that did it. It seems a bit more bendable than the standard PLA and that may be whats throwing it off.
comments.author: tigermcho

comments.text:
i printed your design and want to thank you for sharing it. but moving parts were fused together. is it possible to increase the gaps?
also what was your nozzle size and printing settings?
comments.author: Concerwe

comments.text: Adjust the flow rate in Cula.  I recommend 80~90% flow rate. And my nozzle size is 0.4mm.
comments.author: Concerwe

comments.text: tried a second attempt on prusa and it came out nice. probably the problem was on my delta printer. thanks for reply btw.
